history.content: That is going to be absolutely brutal. Math 104 can be quite challenging (difficulty varies with professor and text). The content of Math 185 assumes familiarity with concepts in 104 (e.g. metric spaces, supremum, continuity). If I were in your shoes and I were forced to do this schedule, I would start self studying 104 ASAP. Some content in 104 (e.g. limits) can also be helpful in 128A. Prof Persson's 128A material can be found here:  http://persson.berkeley.edu/math128a/ if you want to get started watching lectures or learning matlab. Good luck!

The content of Math 185 assumes familiarity with concepts in 104 (e.g. metric spaces, supremum, continuity). If I were in your shoes and I were forced to do this schedule, I would start self studying 104 ASAP. Some content in 104 (e.g. limits) can also be helpful in 128A. Prof Persson's 128A material can be found here:  http://persson.berkeley.edu/math128a/ if you want to get started watching lectures or learning matlab. Gook luck!

children.subject: Just start reading whatever book your professor is using
If you're professor plans on using the Ross textbook, then self-studying Ross might be a good plan, whereas self-studying Rudin might be more difficult since it's such a terse text.
It's totally fine to self-study Rudin also. I don't think it would be much harder

Rudin is an awesome text and if you can muscle your way through it you will be rewarded. However, the thing about Rudin it is that there are many proofs where he doesn't fully explain how he gets from one step to the other. That was my experience when reading it in 104. Now, if you're reading Rudin as your course text this isn't really an issue since you can just ask your professor to help fill in the gaps during office hours. It can be more frustrating if you get stuck while self-studying and don't have professor/GSI/friend on hand.

Another good text for self-study might be Real Mathematical Analysis by Pugh, I've only briefly flipped through it, but it's got many nice visuals that you won't find in the other texts.

That’s how a lot of math books are as you advance further. Maybe I am looking back at it as easier than it was when I read it, but I think it’s worth a try. That kind of textbook really tests that you’re following along as opposed to reading passively
Any recommendations for how to self-study Math 104 during summer?
Do you think getting Cs in them all is too much to ask? I heard EE 120 and Math 128A are light weight classes

No you should be able to get Cs in if you put in sufficient effort, just watch out for 104 and 185. Also I stand by my suggestion of double checking if you can get by with Ds instead, just because it makes your goal a whole lot easier

This schedule sounds hectic and too much for most students to do well in, but that's not what you're aiming for. The good news is that for your situation, you can get grades in the D range but still get credit to graduate provided your major and overall GPA stay > 2.0

That being said, double check all this with an advisor as well ie. don't just take my word for it
Yes, I just need Cs. Thank you for giving some hope <3
i would vote for doable esp if you're just going for Cs
I think you may be overstating the difficulty of 104 and 185 together. To do basic complex analysis, you just need to know calculus well imo

It really depends on the student's background and what the professor demands of you. If your professor has you writing proofs involving open/closed sets in the first week of 185 and you've never heard these terms before, you might be in for a challenge. It wouldn't be surprising if your first 185 hw asks you to show a function is continuous or to take a limit; keep in mind that many students go through the lower division calculus series without ever doing an epsilon-delta proof.
Maybe if you enrolled in the easiest sections for 104 and 185 its doable. 104 with Wodzicki for example would be hard enough by itself.
Doing 185 while doing 104 will be very difficult. If it weren't for that I would say go for it.

<md>Please please please start studying for these courses now. Big bonus if you can find past semester websites for the profs teaching next sem, so you can study the lecture topics from same textbook/do the homeworks. The more you do now the less insane your fall will be.

Oh and plan for your "holidays" (random days off, thanksgiving, WEEKENDS) to just be filled with problem set after problem set. Good luck</md>

history.content: I received a full-time offer and I need to take them all in the Fall in order to graduate in the Fall. Is that schedule doable? I just need to pass (C or above in each).
history.subject: Math 185 + Math 104 + Math 128A + STAT 135 + EE 120
